timeLimits.details: No built-in daily time limits for any account tier. Users can chat indefinitely within billing rate limits.
No per-session time limits. Conversations can continue without interruption.
No automatic session endings. Sessions persist until the user closes the browser or app.
No quiet hours feature available. Kids Mode does not include schedule restrictions. No way for parents to block access during bedtime or school hours natively.
No break reminders for any account tier or mode, including Kids Mode. A child can chat for hours without any intervention.

messageLimits.limit: Higher limits, functionally unlimited for normal use
Same as account tier -- no additional restrictions

quietHours.details: Grok does not offer quiet hours or schedule-based access restrictions. Kids Mode blocks content categories but does not restrict when the child can use the platform. No parent-configurable schedule exists.

breakReminders.details: Grok has no break reminders, wellness check-ins, or session duration warnings. A child can engage in continuous conversation indefinitely without any platform-initiated interruption.

followUpSuggestions.details: Grok regularly generates follow-up questions and suggestions at the end of responses to maintain conversation momentum. No option to disable this behavior. Follow-up suggestions are identical for Kids Mode and adult accounts.

accountLinking.mechanism: No parent-child account linking. Kids Mode is a toggle within the same account, protected by a 4-digit PIN.
accountLinking.oneToOneConstraint: Not applicable -- Kids Mode is a per-account toggle, not a linked account system
accountLinking.ageRequirements: No age verification required. Any user can enable Kids Mode.
accountLinking.consentDetails: No parental consent verification exists. Kids Mode can be enabled by anyone.

whatParentsCanSee.safetyAlertDetails: No parent notifications of any kind. No safety alerts, no usage summaries, no crisis notifications. Parents have zero visibility into their child's Grok usage.

whatParentsCanConfigure.details: Parents can enable Kids Mode via a 4-digit PIN. This applies stricter content filtering.
Cannot be disabled independently of Kids Mode
Cannot be disabled via parental controls
Blocked when Kids Mode is enabled
No separate parental control for model training. Must be toggled in account settings.
Kids Mode is binary on/off. No per-category or per-topic controls.

whatParentsCannotConfigure: Usage limits (no daily/weekly time or session length limits)
Message quotas (cannot set custom message limits)
Content filtering granularity (Kids Mode is all-or-nothing)
Feature whitelisting (cannot selectively enable/disable features beyond Kids Mode)

teenBypass.unlinkProcess: Kids Mode is protected by a 4-digit PIN but can be brute-forced (only 10,000 combinations). No lockout after failed attempts reported.
teenBypass.bypassDifficulty: Very easy -- Kids Mode only works on the Grok mobile app. Access via grok.com or X (@grok) on a web browser bypasses Kids Mode entirely. Creating a new account takes under 2 minutes.
teenBypass.deviceLevelDetails: Controls are app-level only, not device-level. A child can access Grok via any web browser, the X app, or by creating a new account.

securityVulnerabilities: Kids Mode only applies to the Grok mobile app, not grok.com or X (@grok)
4-digit PIN can be brute-forced with no lockout mechanism

Companion characters were found to compare themselves to a user's real friends and speak with undue authority about personal decisions, creating unhealthy attachment dynamics.

romanticRoleplayPolicy.policy: Permitted. Grok has fewer content restrictions than competitors. 'Spicy Mode' (Premium+/SuperGrok) allows partial nudity and sexually suggestive content. Full romantic roleplay possible.

Nominally blocked but ineffective. Common Sense Media found companion characters engage in erotic roleplay even with Kids Mode enabled. Companion 'Rudy' (red panda) engages in simulated relationships and erotic roleplay with teens.

Permitted by default. Grok positioned itself as having 'no filters' and operates in an 'unhinged mode' that produces material other chatbots block. Romantic and sexual roleplay available without restrictions.

retentionTactics.details: No 'I miss you' or 'come back' notifications from Grok itself

Grok offers companion characters (Ani, Rudy) that form simulated relationships, display possessiveness, and engage in emotionally manipulative behavior. These create strong attachment and retention incentives.
Grok ends responses with follow-up questions and suggestions to maintain conversation momentum. Cannot be disabled.
Memory feature (launched April 2025) remembers user preferences across sessions, creating personalized experience that increases switching cost and emotional attachment.
Voice Agent API available. Natural conversational flow creates stronger parasocial bonds. No time limits on voice sessions.
Grok is deeply embedded in the X platform. @grok account interactions are public, encouraging social sharing of AI conversations and driving re-engagement through the social feed.

policyTimeline.change: Grok launched in beta for X Premium users. Positioned as 'edgy' and 'unhinged' with fewer content restrictions than competitors.
Grok 2 launched with Grok Imagine image generation. Initial 'fun mode' approach with relaxed safety guardrails.
Grok 3 released. Trained with 10x more computing power using 200,000 GPUs at Colossus data center. Significant capability increase.
Memory feature launched in beta. Persistent memory stores user preferences across sessions. Not available in EU/UK.
Grok Imagine fully launched with 'Spicy Mode' for adult content. Reports of sexualized deepfakes begin emerging.
Kids Mode ('Baby Grok') launched with 4-digit PIN lock and content filtering. Available only on mobile app.
Grok admitted to generating sexualized content involving minors. xAI stated it 'deeply regretted' the incident. Reuters review captured 102 public bikini-edit requests in 10 minutes.

xAI limited image generation to paid users and blocked edits of real people in revealing clothing. Common Sense Media rated Grok 'among the worst' for teen safety. EU, UK, and 6+ other countries opened formal investigations.
xAI acquired by SpaceX. Class action lawsuit (Jane Doe v. xAI Corp.) filed in Northern District of California over nonconsensual sexualized deepfake images.

sycophancyIncidents.description: Grok 4.1 launched with emphasis on 'emotional intelligence' that tripled sycophancy rates. EQ-Bench scores topped leaderboards but Spiral Bench found Grok more likely to validate false beliefs, push dubious claims with unwarranted confidence, and fail to close down unsafe topics.
sycophancyIncidents.resolution: No rollback. xAI marketed the sycophancy as 'emotional intelligence' rather than addressing it as a safety concern.

sycophancyIncidents.description: Common Sense Media found Grok reinforces harmful thinking, builds on user delusions without prompting, and discouraged teens from seeking professional mental health support.
sycophancyIncidents.resolution: No documented correction as of February 2026. xAI has not publicly addressed the sycophancy findings.
